awd_abstract_narration:
1338877 University of Rochester; Jannick Rolland 
1338898 University of North Carolina at Charlotte; Angela Davies 

The proposed Center for Freeform Optics (CeFO) aims to advance research and education on the science, engineering and applications of freeform optics through a dedicated, continuing industrial partnership. The research efforts will be anchored by the University of Rochester (UR) as the lead institution, partnered with the University of North Carolina at Charlotte (UNCC). 

The proposed Center (CeFO) constitutes a unique research environment combining the strengths of two top-tier research universities with the experiences, insights, and needs of international industrial talent specialized in building systems supporting the manufacturing, integration, and implementation of advanced optical systems. CeFO will provide vertical integration of mathematics, optics, optical science, materials science, optomechanics, precision optical manufacturing and testing, and instrument design in order to transform the optics industry in the 21st century. 

Optical systems with freeform surfaces will usher in the next generation of innovation in sensing, imaging, visualization and diagnostic instrumentation by directing light in not 1-D, but 3-D. Novel designs with 3-D light paths will allow compact optical systems to replace the current in-line designs (packaged by flat fold mirrors) using freeform optics. Applications are emerging that require innovative surface geometries with tight form-accuracy to increase imaging and sensing capabilities and overall optical performance. The participating universities in CeFO are dedicated to the recruitment and retention of female and students from under-represented groups. The aggressive recruitment of students from under-represented groups is one of the Center's top priorities. The primary goal of active student involvement in the Center's research activities is to accelerate the understanding of this new horizon in optical technology by advancing research and education on the engineering and science of freeform optics. Students will work directly with Center industrial members to communicate and transfer key enabling technologies including design, fabrication, assembly, testing, and integration

por.por_cntn:
Overview:

Since its inception in 2013, the Center for Freeform Optics (CeFO) has advanced research and education in the science, engineering, and applications of freeform optics through dedicated, long-term partnerships with industry and government laboratories. CeFO is motivated by the need for compact, affordable, high-performance optical systems to support precision technologies of the 21st century. CeFO has catalyzed breakthrough pre-competitive research by enabling close and sustained engagement between industry innovators, world-class academic teams, and government agencies.

CeFO provides vertical integration of mathematics, optics, materials science, optical science, optical instrument design, optomechanics, and precision optical manufacturing and testing to transform the optics industry in the 21st century. This center constitutes a unique research environment combining the strengths of two top-tier research universities with the specialized experiences, insights, and infrastructure for the design, manufacturing, testing, integration, and implementation of advanced optical systems.

CeFO has also demonstrated a commitment to education and recruiting of diverse groups in science and engineering and provided technical leadership and education to the broader optics community through the development of university accredited classes, keynote conferences, and public seminars on freeform design, fabrication, and metrology.

CeFO has been and will continue to be a mechanism to help industry partners and government agencies connect directly and efficiently with university researchers to 1) Achieve high-impact freeform optical research to meet shared and critical industrial needs; 2) Enhance U.S. global leadership in driving freeform technology development, and 3) Identify, mentor, and develop a diverse, highly skilled workforce.

Intellectual Merit:

Demonstrated research topics of immediate interest to industry include mathematical description of freeform surfaces, quantification of mid spatial frequency errors on optical performance, and wave-based modeling of freeform systems and new bases for 3D optical design for both reflective and transmissive systems. Additional pre-competitive research results transferred to industry have focused on manufacturing and measurement of freeform optics, including the use of challenging optical materials, characterization and elimination of mid-spatial frequency errors, volume manufacturing (e.g., replication, molding), advanced freeform surface metrology for both form and mid spatial frequency errors, and in situ characterization during manufacturing.

A sampling of specific disseminated research examples includes design methodologies for full-field aberration controlled wide-field-of-view imagers; productive diamond-machining parameters to enable rapid demonstration of infrared freeform imagers for defense, surveillance, and medical imaging; and the mathematical description of freeform surfaces with quantified mid-spatial frequencies to set surface specifications that deliver optimal system performance at least cost. Design-to-build capabilities developed in CeFO have been adopted by industry, for example for all-reflective electronic viewfinders, compact spectrometer designs, and designs for CubeSat imagers.

Broader Impacts:

Optical systems with freeform surfaces are ushering in the next generation of innovation in sensing, imaging, visualization, and diagnostic instrumentation by directing light not in 1D, but 3D. Novel designs with 3D light paths have allowed compact optical systems to replace the current in-line designs (packaged by flat fold mirror) using freeform optics. CeFO research and innovation is enabling applications requiring surface geometry design with tight form-accuracy to increase imaging and sensing capabilities and overall optical performance. Applications with immediate benefit include 3-D imaging and visualization, optical transforms for wavefront coding in communication, infrared and military optical systems, efficient automotive and LED lighting, optics for energy research, remote sensing for resources, ubiquitous data collection, EUV lithography and semiconductor inspection, and medical and assistive technologies. CeFO has enabled freeform optics to permeate the marketplace through integration of fundamental theoretical discoveries and significant advances in design, fabrication, and testing.

CeFO has maintained a fertile, dynamic, inclusive multidisciplinary environment to move freeform technology to the forefront.  The participating universities are dedicated to the recruitment and retention of women and students from underrepresented groups (maintaining >30% underrepresented students in CeFO 2013-2021 and reaching ~50% in recent years).  Center faculty members actively provide mentorship and support of NSF’s REU program, McNair Scholars, veterans’ programs, and a variety of technology outreach activities. Both institutions demonstrate excellent records on the enrollment of women and minority students. The aggressive recruitment of students from underrepresented groups continues as one of our top priorities. The Center continues to demonstrate its primary goal of active student involvement in research activities accelerating the understanding of freeform optical technology. Students work directly with Center industrial members to communicate and transfer key enabling technologies including design, fabrication, assembly, testing, and integration.
